maml:description.maml:para: Get bitly links associated with your group
Use this command to get links associated with your group ID which you can find as part of your user object.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter your Bitly group GUID or ID.
Enter your Bitly API token
Filter for links created after this date.
Filter for links created before this date.
Enter a key word or phrase to filter on.
Filter for links modified after this date.
Specify the number of links to return. The default is 50. The limit for this command is 1000.
Filter links by tags.
Enter your Bitly API token
Filter for links created after this date.
Filter for links created before this date.
Enter a key word or phrase to filter on.
Enter your Bitly group GUID or ID.
Filter for links modified after this date.
Specify the number of links to return. The default is 50. The limit for this command is 1000.
Filter links by tags.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-BitlyUser | Get-BitlyGroupLinks
Created : 10/21/2019 5:12:15 AM Link : http://bit.ly/2oY3qty CustomLinks : {} Title : Securing PowerShell Tags : {class, PowerShell} ID : bit.ly/2oY3qty Url : https://www.dropbox.com/s/353ndxn9ntowmlf/SecuringPowerShell.zip
Created : 9/22/2019 7:46:54 PM Link : http://bit.ly/2kZgOeW CustomLinks : {http://bit.ly/PowerShell-Advanced-Spiceworld2019} Title : PowerShell Advanced Spiceworld 2019 Tags : {conference, powershell} ID : bit.ly/2kZgOeW Url : https://www.dropbox.com/s/7kdjfc7fvvjvjtr/PowerShell-Advanced-Spiceworld2019.zip?dl=0
Created : 9/22/2019 7:44:45 PM Link : http://bit.ly/2mvnz8X CustomLinks : {http://bit.ly/PowerShell-Fundamentals-Spiceworld2019} Title : PowerShell Fundamentals Spiceworld 109 Tags : {conference, powershell} ID : bit.ly/2mvnz8X Url : https://www.dropbox.com/s/pjal0m0lgxeds8h/PowerShell-Fundamentals-Spiceworld2019.zip?dl=0
...

maml:description.maml:para: If you have a bitly link, like bit.ly/ABC123, you can use this command to retrieve the link object from the bitly service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>
Enter your Bitly API token
Enter your Bitly API token
Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-bitlylink -id bit.ly/2oY3qty
Created : 10/21/2019 5:12:15 AM Link : http://bit.ly/2oY3qty CustomLinks : {} Title : Securing PowerShell Tags : {class, PowerShell} ID : bit.ly/2oY3qty Url : https://www.dropbox.com/s/353ndxn9ntowmlf/SecuringPowerShell.zip

maml:description.maml:para: Get a summary of clicks for a bitly link.
You can use this command to get a summary of clicks for a given bitly link over a specified time frame.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>
Enter your Bitly API token
An integer representing the time units to query data for. Use -1 to return all units of time.
The number of items to return.
Enter a unit of time
Enter your Bitly API token
An integer representing the time units to query data for. Use -1 to return all units of time.
Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>
The number of items to return.
Enter a unit of time

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-BitlyLinkSummary bit.ly/2KJtUqP -Timespan month -Count 3
ID TotalClicks Timespan Count Date -- ----------- -------- ----- ---- bit.ly/2KJtUqP 426 month 3 11/13/2019 3:56:01 PM

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get a link summary for the last 3 months.

maml:description.maml:para: Use this command to get your bitly user object. You might need the GroupID value for other commands.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter your Bitly API token
Enter your Bitly API token

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-bitlyuser
Name : Art Deco Email : artd@Company.com GroupID : Xb3s9XYawRX Created : 3/28/2017 5:37:39 AM Modified : 11/2/2018 11:27:22 AM

maml:description.maml:para: Get online details from a url
This command will retrieve metadata about a given URL using Invoke-WebRequest. It should work for any URL.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a URL in the form http:// or https://
Enter a URL in the form http:// or https://

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-urldetail http://bit.ly/2CHVAYy
URL : http://bit.ly/2CHVAYy AbsoluteURL : https://www.dropbox.com/s/5iz1vvhvtbfxdcd/CreatingRESTTools.zip Title : Dropbox - CreatingRESTTools.zip - Simplify your life Date : 11/13/2019 4:14:32 PM

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new bitly link from a given url. You can use Set-Bitlylink to customize it once it has been created.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the long url to shorten
Enter your Bitly API token
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter your Bitly API token
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the long url to shorten
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-BitlyLink -url https://github.com/powershell/powershell
Created : 12/31/1969 7:00:00 PM Link : http://bit.ly/32GPRwt CustomLinks : {} Title : Tags : {} ID : bit.ly/32GPRwt Url : https://github.com/powershell/powershell

maml:description.maml:para: Save your bitly API key or token to a secure file.

Use of the bitly REST API requires an API key or token, which you can setup under your account online. Most commands in this module require the token for authentication purposes. To protect the token and make it easier to use the commands, you can run Save-Bitlytoken to store the token as a secure string in a file. The file is called bitlytoken.xml and is stored in your $home (~) directory. You will be prompted to enter or paste your token which is immediately saved as a secure string. This string is then exported to a cliXML file. This file can only be decrypted by you on the machine where it was created.
When you import the PSBitly module, if this file is found, it will be decrypted and the value stored as a secure string in a PSDefaultParameter value for the bitly commands.

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Save-BitlyToken -WhatIf Enter or copy your Bitly API key or token.: *********************

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should be able to paste the token at the Read-Host prompt.

maml:description.maml:para: You this command to update an existing link. You might want to add a tag or title. Custom links must be added manually online.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>
Enter your Bitly API token
THIS PARAMETER IS UNDER DEVELOPMENT
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
specify a set of tags
Add a title
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter your Bitly API token
THIS PARAMETER IS UNDER DEVELOPMENT
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the bitly link i.e. bit.ly/<short>
specify a set of tags
Add a title
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-BitlyLink -id bit.ly/32GPRwt -title "Open Source PowerShell" -tags "github","powershell"
Created : 11/13/2019 4:19:55 PM Link : http://bit.ly/32GPRwt CustomLinks : {} Title : Open Source PowerShell Tags : {github, powershell} ID : bit.ly/32GPRwt Url : https://github.com/powershell/powershell
